summary: china has transitioned from being one of the fastest-growing populations to among the most rapidly aging countries worldwide. the population of oldest-old individuals, those 80+, is projected to quadruple by 2050. the oldest-old represent a uniquely important group—they have high demand for personal assistance and the highest healthcare costs of any age group. gains in partial LE and DFLE primarily occurred among the urban resident population. successive generations of china’s oldest-old are living with less disability as a whole. but we found a widening urban-rural disparity in longevity and disability. proportion of remaining partial life expectancy spent disability-free and disabled in ages 80–89, 90–99, and 100–105 across 10 years birth cohorts, both sexes combined.
